1118605115970281473.text: The price movement may have begun on HitBTC’s Bitcoin-Tether market with a matched trade of 122 Bitcoin at 04:23 UTC. This is equivalent to an order of approximately 500,000 Tether sold in one transaction.pic.twitter.com/BI6XjkQ43M

1118604747005734912.text: The large price movement on April 2, 2019 occurred during the window of lowest global liquidity. It began at 04:30 UTC and lasted until 05:30 UTC. This time may have been deliberately chosen so that a committed actor could maximize price impact when trading.pic.twitter.com/vktxpGBwlQ

1118604503471808513.text: Large trades were observed on HitBTC’s BTC-USDT market immediately prior to the price movement, although we cannot rule out wash trading at HitBTC. Large trades were then observed on Coinbase’s BTC-USD market followed by Bitfinex’s BTC-USD market.

1118604279886024706.text: Although this cannot be known for sure, such trades would have been designed to trigger stop losses and force a short squeeze through liquidations of margin positions and short futures positions.

1118604037522374656.text: Our theory is that a single committed actor went long and traded in a manner that maximized price impact. The movement in price started at 04:30 UTC time, the point in the day where global liquidity is at a minimum.

1118603934183116802.text: Several explanations were put forward including a response to an April Fool’s article or that a single buyer went long with notional value of approximately $100 million.

1118603910522994688.text: On April 2, 2019, Bitcoin’s price increased from roughly $4,200 to $5,000 in a span of one hour. There was no impactful news released during this time.

1118593998657081344.text: How to interpret the above chart: of the 73m ETH active in the last 12 months, the average unit has changed hands 10 times in that period (after our adjustment which removes noise, self-spends, and other artifacts)

1074046230458703872.text: Keep in mind that active supply is very different from onchain tx value, and is a less gameable metric. Active supply looks at the number of units that moved _at least once_ in a given period, with no double counting.

1074045417187368960.text: Interestingly, the 6 month period ending November 2018 was the 2nd least active period since 2010, with only 25% of BTC active in that period. Only the 6 month period ending Oct. 2015 was lower with 24% of supply active.

1074044688896794625.text: In nominal terms, June 2018 saw the peak for the raw number of BTC active in the prior 12 months, at just over 10m (out of 17.5m possible). But in relative terms, 2012 was the most active period, with 67% of supply moving in a 12 month period (see above)pic.twitter.com/oiL2mpceph

1074043716531302400.text: A couple notes on BTC active supply. Historically, between 40 and 70% of Bitcoin supply changes hands in a given 12 month period. For 6 months, this ranges between 25% and 60%.pic.twitter.com/yaPvIhZbkO

1065630395364978689.text: Four-megabyte blocks are theoretically possible, but normal Bitcoin usage would never generate these. UTXO-consolidation blocks can stretch into the 3mb range though.

1065630015197462528.text: This chart summarizes our findings. Right now about 45% of Bitcoin transfers use SegWit and signature data is about 65% of transactions, so blocks are around 1.2 mb.pic.twitter.com/dO1rh95Pz8

1065629674557120512.text: Answering "how big will Bitcoin blocks get" is a more complex task than you might imagine. While the theoretical limit is 4mb, more realistically, blocks will be in the 1.7-2.2 mb range at full adoption

1065629315549802498.text: New post: in this blog, we explore the drivers of transaction size in the post-SegWit era.https://coinmetrics.io/what-should-we-expect-from-bitcoins-block-size-in-the-coming-years/ …

1065360903695151110.text: This got so interesting we decided to create a quick visualization showing how big blocks will get assuming various patterns of Segwit adoption and usage

1065309929064534021.text: Will full Segwit adoption and bech32 usage, typical blocks will be around 1.8 mb, although consolidation blocks (lots of inputs) will run as large as 2.5-3 mb

1056620708787355648.text:
A note on the changing tides in Bitcoin. Daily onchain volume (gold) is 2% of market cap, near its previous bear market lows. But exchange volume (blue) has steadily increased relative to market cap. So aggregate liquidity (green) is robust. 

https://coinmetrics.io/charts/#assets=btc_log=false__sameAxisComparison=true …pic.twitter.com/DHyClItWs2

1056400960237568001.text: An interesting takeaway is that there is a not only an absolute increase, year on year, in Bitcoin exchange volume, but also a relative increase. Exchange volumes relative to market cap are reliably increasing too.

1056400467411001346.text: Now we've made the numbers comparable and we can take the average (green line above). Looks like there is no seasonality. Exchange volume averages about 2% of Bitcoin's market cap with little month to month deviation.

1056399801082884096.text: This is problematic, because there were massive bull runs in some of these years, so exchange volumes will be trended. What if we de-trended by taking exchange volume as a percentage of network value?pic.twitter.com/VDKaJ5MN2B

1056399454180466688.text: First, here are the raw numbers, formatted on a log view, because volumes are radically different between 2014 and 2018. Hmm... no obvious trendpic.twitter.com/bZdhEfwTKl

1056399178832715776.text: Note that we're talking about trading volume at exchanges, not on-chain volume.

1056399071001411584.text: Are Bitcoin exchange volumes seasonal? I.e. are they markedly lower in the summer months, as with equities? A brief investigation.

1040426350044172288.text: This is also why effective inflation is higher than expected inflation in Bitcoin.

1040426172574822400.text: Note that the mean here is _not_ 144 as you might expect (1440 minutes in a day, one block every 10 minutes), but higher, due to the progressive increase in hash power over time (and slow-to-react difficulty adjustments)

1025538554871668742.text: Note that we're not weighing in on the legitimacy of USDT creation or their backed-ness. We felt that actual usage data is often omitted in the broader analysis, and wanted to share.

1025535224984285184.text: This isn't definitive proof one way or the other... but all of the USDT usage patterns indicate a network which has robust and continued usage, and usage which is proportional to its network value. We encourage you to investigate for yourselves.https://coinmetrics.io/charts/#assets=usdt_roll=7_left=txVolume_right=marketcap_zoom=1430102205248.0723,1533168000000 …

1025534715846189056.text:
Another way to spot txn value spoofing is for transaction value to spike with a set of abnormally large transactions. However median and mean txn value have grown normally over time. 

https://coinmetrics.io/charts/#assets=usdt_log=false_roll=14_left=medianTxValue_right=avgTxValue_zoom=1439576954173.9004,1533168000000_sameAxisComparison=true …pic.twitter.com/RKoNXdY3ks

1025534258859966464.text:
In some cases, high transaction count is fabricated – either for a stress test or metric gaming. The easy way to check for this is to look at active addresses; oftentimes it is just a few addresses making txns. But addresses have grown with txn count. 

https://coinmetrics.io/charts/#assets=usdt_log=false_roll=7_left=txCount_right=activeAddresses_sameAxisComparison=true …pic.twitter.com/8rRHCfZHjZ

1025533343864107008.text: Of course, like with any chain, a consortium of insiders could be gaming the figures to deliberately create a narrative. Let's use our usual checks – median transaction size, active addresses, and txn count

1025532633265172480.text:

As are LTC and ZEC. Interestingly, BCH is trading at a premium relative to where you'd expect it to be priced based on the BCH liquidity / BTC liquidity ratio.

1013780455563448322.text:
Toying with this concept of 'aggregate liquidity'. The idea is that on- and off-chain volume (exchanges) are two complementary components of global liquidity. We standardized it in BTC terms rather than USD to make the chart readable. 

https://coinmetrics.io/charts/#assets=btc_log=false_zoom=1482961914844.1475,1530403200000_ …pic.twitter.com/Atkd1jNvuG

https://coinmetrics.io/charts/#assets=btc_log=false_zoom=1439500193485.9663,1530316800000_ …pic.twitter.com/SvrrtpvucP

1013614053271457792.text: Why compare on-chain and exchange? Well a significant fraction of on-chain volumes is related to exchange activity – they are two sides of the same coin. There combined trend is an interesting look at aggregate liquidity, on and off chain.

1013613464454123520.text: On-chain in blue, exchange in gold, the combination in green. You can see that adjusted on-chain volumes in BTC terms are at a low not seen since may 2015. However, exchange volumes remain strong, so aggregate turnover is at Oct 2017 levels.

988831421157511174.text: The point of forward-looking returns is to perform a historical backtest. You can answer questions like "when this ratio was [high/low], what was Bitcoin's actual return over the following [week/month/year]?"

988831003069251589.text: Some familiarity with our chart builder is required. If you want to change the forward-looking return period, change the number in "period is 30".https://coinmetrics.io/charts/#assets=btc_log=false_ …

988830789394681856.text:
We built a "forward-looking returns" tool so you can test the predictiveness of ratios or other indicators. 

In black - historical 30-day returns. ("What was the BTC return over the following month if I invested on x day?") In blue - NVT smoothed over 2 weeks.pic.twitter.com/f0bUYoIJba

988770557628964864.text: Please note that tx count is encoding more outputs thanks to batching. Our "best guess" of the batching quotient means that a given transaction will encode roughly 10-15% more outputs than it did 6 months ago. So mentally boost the tx count line.
